context.speaker: David Toren

context.speaker: Potter Stewart

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Did the Commission anywhere in its rules or anywhere else advised Pipe Lines that if they enter into a contract to take natural gas and they come to the Commission and get a certificate of convenience and necessity that the contract term does not mean what an ordinarily means that's really the position here, isn't it?

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: That is to say if the Commission basic position here it seems to me is that the Pipe Line makes a contract with a producer that the term limitation, the limitation of the contract as to time is subject to nullification by the Commission or to quite add more accurately that the contract continues indefinitely regardless of the terms classified therein unless the Commission otherwise permits by order, is that what this is about?

context.speaker: Peter H. Schiff

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: It's the duties under the contract continue indefinitely but your rights end when the contract ends.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In other words, your duty continues to take the gas but then on the seller after the expiration of contract of sellers sets the price in which you take it.

context.text: But interestingly enough allegedly for a “tax gimmick” they had it paid to a dummy corporation which of course turned out to be Tucker and Norris' dummy corporation so that the subcontractor was able to cover up that by giving it to this dummy corporation.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: A subcontractor owes his subcontractor a bribe cannot be considered fully liable and to take all the type of protection that they seem to offer.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The price of the subcontract may well be inflated by more than the amount of the kickbacks.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: For a subcontractor who have -- expects to obtain a subcontract in exchange for a bribe has less incentive to make a realistic appraisal of either cost or profit.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And unless the Government is entitled to cancel, it will be bound to contracts like this one here conceived in corruptness and on that conceived and corruptness, I come back to your question, Mr. Justice Brennan, not the corruptness of Acme as such but the corruptness of people that Acme has taken in and given responsible positions.
